advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRIMO ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID SITUATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>A translation would be : "the 10 years old and more children appreciate quickly the computing principles and have a lot of fun with their ZX-80" <br><br> So they say...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The columbia MPC is shipped with fully suported software that will save you $3,000. Included is the entire self-teaching Perfect Software family: Perfect Writer, a word processor; Perfect Speller, a 50,000 word dictionnary; Perfect Filer, a data base manager; and Perfect Calc, a financial calculation system.<br><br> In addition, you get MS-DOS, CP/M-86, Macro/86 assembler, BASICA, Asynchronous communication support, Diagnostics and the Columbia Tutor program...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''It's time''<br> ''ATMOS from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Stop everything !''<br> ''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #3 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>As harware arguments wasn't sufficient, NothStar tried to promote software compatability and services.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TI 88/4A. The family computer.<br> It's easy. Connect it, connect yourself."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>One found the same leaflet in various countries, translated in many languages.<br><br> Title was: 'Sirius 1, the professional computer to the power of 16' </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The new Epson QX-10 is unlike any personal computer you've never seen. It's a computer for people who don't have the time to learn computer; a computer you can be using within minutes...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE FLYER - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Tennis (1 player), Tennis (2 players), Soccer, Squash
computer.coprocessor: Service auto/manual, Ball speed pro/am, Ball angle pro/am, Paddle size pro/am
computer.description: This is exactly the same system as the Radofin Tele-Sports, but sold by Ultrasound in Germany. See the Radofin Tele-Sports entry for more info.
computer.keyboard: Two paddles with big dials (black model) or sliders (wooden model) and no fire button
computer.language: Tennis (1 player), Tennis (2 players), Soccer, Squash
computer.name: Tele-Sports
computer.ports: RF TV video output, power in
computer.ram: On system front panel (0 - 10) and on screen
